                        IntroductionCultural historical buildings represent a form of expression which frames certain feelings and describes the social and economical state of societies within a given moment. It is necessary to preserve these constructions for the next generation because of their great historical value, which allows us to understand various aspects of societies, such as their history and development. These cultural heritage conservation processes are supported by a series of problem-solving perspectives and tools that allow the identification of materials and considerations from the point of view of technique and technology used by artists for their intentions and creative process1,2,3,4,5. Little is known about the environmental impact of geographical location on heritage buildings, especially of those located in tropical countries, along with the intention of its construction and it is not clear what factors represent a key challenge to ensure the conservation of the artworks in these atmospheres.Therefore, this pilot study seeks to remedy these challenges by analyzing the environmental conditions of the Management’s Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR [built in 1891-1897]) and to determine their impact on the large-format paintings located within this chamber (see Fig. 1 for our artistic visualization). The NTCR is a historical building that represents society’s desire to experience various expressions of art locally, like other theaters’ intent throughout Europe and Latin America6. In this building, the south and east sides are lined with typically busy streets (pedestrians and vehicles), while the north and west sides have a plaza where many pigeons live and where people pass through all day long. The MO is located in the southwest corner of the building (Fig. 2) and is decorated with wall-to-wall murals and a large-format oil painting on the ceiling, all painted by Italian artist Paolo Serra. Environmental conditions play an important role in the maintenance of these historic buildings, especially those that shelter important artworks that are exposed to climate changes and different conditions since the time of its construction7,8. Therefore, environmental conditions could be a major factor, causing degradation damage to historic heritage if there are no climatized systems that keep the temperature and relative humidity under control, independently of the external conditions. Another important practical implication is that when the historic buildings are open to the public, there are greater probabilities that the temperature, humidity, airborne microorganisms, internal microclimate, and the energy performance of the entire system will vary8.To a limited extent, three methods have been identified as being potentially important for keeping the internal environmental conditions of historic buildings under control: (1) natural ventilation, (2) forced ventilation and (3) air conditioning. Most historic buildings were designed and built using natural ventilation (1), accordingly, it is an additional challenge to make modifications that allow the inclusion of any of the other types of techniques, namely (2) and (3), especially in those that contain cultural heritage without causing structural harm or several major drawbacks to the artworks9. It has been shown that there is an unambiguous relationship between temperature variations and paintings, specifically thermal fatigue could be generated, which has possible connections to the artworks’ damages10. It is worth mentioning that the NTCR only has an air conditioning system in the main chamber, yet the rest of the rooms do not have controlled environmental conditions. The MO chamber has three large windows that are periodically opened. The artworks are not exposed to the public, except for special visitors with controlled access, including diplomats, researchers, conservators, restorers, and visitors by appointment or formal invitation. The access door to this room is located on the north side, next to the main entrance of the building. Once inside, one can appreciate the large format paintings that delicately decorate all the walls and ceiling of the chamber. The study’s objective was to examine these large-format paintings exhibited under non-controlled environmental conditions from an interdisciplinary viewpoint for evidence findings that methodically assess the conservation state, i.e. the deterioration and biodeterioration, chromatic alteration, and the artist’s color palette (Fig. 1). Finally, our aim is therefore to provide a systematic correlation between these parameters and deterioration that can be identified in the artworks. It is worth mentioning that in previous works at the NTCR, we observed a new fungal species associated with damaging cultural heritage11: we distinguished particular fluorescent areas which were recognized through its red-coral fluorescence as Madder Lake12, we identified Carlo Ferrario’s main colour palette, along with we successfully achieved the characterization of eight genera of calcareous nannofossils found in the ground layers of his artwork13. Carlo Ferrario was an Italian artist, who was commissioned to paint Musas I and Musas II, two of the most important and representative paintings of the NTCR. However, our goal of having a deeper understanding of the inexorable complexity which surrounds the artwork’s habitat, colour modification suitable to environmental adaptation, and the pictorial materials used by artists from respective epochs to devise a historic building that has remained elusive.Fig. 1Multidisciplinary approach to the study of the effect of environmental conditions on the artworks found in the Management’s Office of the National Theater of Costa Rica. This study aims to describe how temperature, relative humidity, air flow and microbial colonization have deteriorated the murals, and the ceiling painted by the Italian artist Paolo Serra. The room is decorated with Pompeian inspired art and is located at the entrance of the theater, in the southwest corner. As shown in the illustration, it has three windows facing the outside environment where air, light and diverse microorganisms can enter the venue. Evelyn María Zamora Conejo partially created the figure. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imageFig. 2Location of the Management Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR). (A) The MO is located in the southwest corner of the NTCR, bordered to the south by one of the Capitals’ main streets, and a plaza, filled with pigeons and pedestrians, to the west. (B) The room has three windows that are usually open throughout the week and a door that leads to the theater’s entrance hallway. As shown in the panel (C), the room is completely decorated with paintings by Italian artist Paolo Serra, in a clear Pompeian style. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imagePaolo SerraPaolo Serra was an Italian painter trained at the academies of Naples and Florence. Later, he worked as a teacher at the Academy of Rome. After that, he traveled to Costa Rica to fulfill a contract that entrusted him with painting part of the decorative artworks of the NTCR. Upon completing these paintings, he settled permanently in the country where he carried out other commissions, such as the paintings for the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Heredia, the old Casa Cural of the Villa de Barva in Heredia, and the Chapel of the Hospicio Carlos María Ulloa. Unfortunately, out of these three places, only the painting of Hospicio has survived14,15.Serra’s style was distinguished by its dynamism, intense chromaticism, and a clear influence by Pompeian murals. He used to decorate his paintings with decorative borders, frequently using repeated motifs that he may have executed using molds. There are variations in the painter’s signatures: in some of the works at the NTCR, he signed as Paolo, while in others he used the name Pablo. This could be due to an adaptation to the Latin American context of the time or, perhaps, to the fact that one of his assistants signed on his behalf, a common practice at that time. For this research, two types of artworks were analyzed: oil on canvas attached to the ceiling and a mural on the west elevation composed of four paintings to complete the chamber known as MO. Both artworks were produced in 1897 by Paolo Serra (1860-1900), as part of the construction of the NTCR. In addition to the mural paintings at the NTCR, a few easel works are known, such as landscapes, still life, and portraits, which are currently part of private collections. Paolo Serra died on December 9, 1900, in the city of Heredia at the age of 40.Results and discussionIdentification of deteriorations in the artworks under studyPhotographs in the visible (VIS) and ultraviolet (UV) spectrum were generated for each of the paintings studied. Examples of these pictures are presented in Figs. 2B, 5, and 6. Based on the analysis of the photographs and ocular inspection carried out in situ at the NTCR, several damages and significant deterioration were identified. As a guide to determine the type of damage the following bibliography was consulted: Australian Institute for the Conservation of Cultural Material Inc (AICCM)16, Mayorga17 and Calvo18. Supplementary Table 2 shows the definition and general characterization of these deteriorations found and Table 1 presents the identification number, name and percentage of damage, and the quadrants in which each is presented in the painting of the MO ceiling. For example, cracks were identified in all the quadrants. The damages are also illustrated with an image of the actual damage found in each of the artworks in question and their location according to the previously established grid. Fig. 5B illustrates the damages found in the painting of the ceiling. It is worth mentioning that, as an example of the identification of the damages, a zoom of the grid number 28 is presented, which has many damages identified by different colors: cracking, cracks, excrement of insects, opaque spots, exposed support, holes, and scratches.Table 1 Table of damages by quadrant on Management Office ceiling (Danthe y Rafael).Full size tableAerial microorganisms contamination of the NTCRThe fungal aerial concentration of seven rooms of the NTCR (i.e. Hall next to the Ladies’ Cafeteria, Men’s Canteen, Hall next to the Men’s Canteen, MO, Smoking Lounge for Ladies, Smoking Lounge for Men, and the Presidential Theater Box, see Supplementary Figure S1) was determined throughout the year 2022. As described in the Methods section, one monthly sampling was carried out, except for June and December for reasons beyond the control of the study. In June, Hurricane Bonnie prevented visitors from entering the facility, and in December the NTCR was closed for the holiday season. Therefore, the results reflect data collected during the ten months of the year under study.Table 2 shows the fungal aerial concentration by cubic meter of the seven rooms sampled. The highest mean concentration was found in the Hall attached to the Ladies’ Cafeteria (1355 ± 459 spores/m³) and the lowest in the Smoking Lounge for Ladies (701 ± 275 spores/m³). However, the NTCR MO presented the highest concentration of all the samplings during April (4408 spores/m³). This was the month that presented the highest mean fungal concentration (1610 ± 1368 spores/m³), while July was the lowest (548 ± 174 spores/m³). Significant statistical differences were found between the fungal aerial concentration of each month (F = 2.264; df = 9; p = 0.03). The data was divided into three groups: the first group included the months of March and July, the second group January, February, May, August, September, October, and November; and only April in the third group. This indicates that the months with lower concentrations (March and July) presented significant differences respect to the other months of the year, which in turn, showed significant differences compared to April, the month with the highest concentration. It is worth noting that the high fungal concentrations found in April are due to the levels found in the NTCR’s MO. In Fig. 3A, the boxplot graphic of the monthly measurements of the fungal aerial concentration of all the rooms sampled is presented and includes specifically the value of Cladosporium spp. fungal spore concentration since this is presented in the biggest amount, so that is the most representative. It is worth mentioning that similar results have been documented for other indoor environments in Costa Rica. In a study conducted inside three schools located in the Province of Heredia, high fungal aerial concentrations were reported during the months of May and October (rainy season, ranging from 3194 to 3747 spores/m³) and the lowest on March (1392 ± 120 spores/m³). Once again, the main fungal spore identified belonged to the genus Cladosporium19. On the other hand, a study analyzing the fungal aerial concentration of the outside environment of an academic institution found much lower concentrations with a yearly mean of 444 ± 202 spores/m³. Eighteen types of spores were identified, the majority of which were sexual spores20. These results exemplify the importance of ventilation of enclosed spaces, since a lack of ventilation could result in a concentration of spores.Table 2 Fungal aerial concentration of seven rooms of the Costa Rican National Theater (TNCR), during 2022.Full size tableFig. 3Aerial microbiological contamination of the Management Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR). This is relevant because there is a correlation between high spore concentrations and occupational risk in asthmatic workers and those allergic to Penicillium and/or Alternaria alternata21. It is worth noting that Penicillium is one of the main genera of fungi found throughout the NTCR’s air and walls22. Additionally, the entire enclosure in which Serra’s artworks are located could be bio deteriorated by these fungi. The latter happens because paintings are made of different materials composed of organic and inorganic molecules, which under the right environmental conditions, can lead to the colonization of a wide variety of microorganisms that cause both aesthetic and structural deterioration23. Therefore, additional experiments were carried out to evaluate the fungal and bacterial contamination of this chamber. Seventeen sampling sites were selected for passive and active air samplings (see Fig. 3B) and 34 for microbiological isolation (ten from the murals and 24 from the ceiling) (see Fig. 5B).Aerial contamination of the MODue to the high fungal aerial concentration found in the MO during the 2022 campaign, additional experiments were carried out to evaluate the fungal and bacterial contamination of this chamber (refer to Methods section Microbial Contamination of the MO). Seventeen sampling sites were selected for passive and active air monitoring in this room (see Fig. 3B). The results of these sampling are presented in Table 3.Table 3 Passive and active air sampling of the Management’s Office.Full size tableAs seen in Table 3, the north side and southeast corner were the places within the MO with the highest concentrations of both fungi and bacteria. There are two factors that can explain the high concentration of microorganisms in these areas. Firstly, this chamber has a window facing one of the busiest streets in terms of traffic and pedestrians in the province of San José (“Avenida Segunda”, in Spanish) and another one facing the Culture Place (“Plaza de la Cultura”, in Spanish). Thus, the highest concentration of microorganisms was found close to these windows, coinciding with the way the air circulates inside the chamber. It is worth noting that a correlation between exposure to environmental pollution with increase in spore concentration has been documented; also, temperature increases during the dry season relate to increasing human activities that cause pollution24. This could explain the fact that April was the month with the highest concentration, as it coincides with the dry season in Costa Rica. Another finding that supports this hypothesis is the high concentration of ascospores and basidiospores (Supplementary Table 1). These fungi have been described as the dominant biological particles in aerobiological studies of tropical areas, which are dispersed through the air and whose dispersion is dependent on humidity25. Basidiomycetes, for example, are part of various organic cycles degrading substrates such as cellulose and lignin, which are also components of different artistic works. Additionally, Trichaptum abietinum has been described to produce laccase and peroxidase activity, which can decolorate different aromatic dyes used in a wide spectrum of artistic productions26.Furthermore, the second factor that affects the spore aerial concentration is the colonization of walls and ceilings a matter that is being discussed in the following section.Isolation of microorganisms from the murals and ceiling of the MO34 regions of interest (ten from the murals and 24 from the ceiling [see Supplementary Figure 2]), for possible microbial growth, were identified after the analysis of the paintings’ deterioration maps. Six out of the ten sampling sites selected on the murals were positive for microbial growth. Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Cladosporium cladosporioides complex, Yarrowia lipolytica (Candida lipolytica) and a hyaline non-identified fungal isolate were retrieved from the east side of the north wall from a crack with loss of support. Penicillium citrinum and a hyaline non-identified fungi were retrieved from another crack with loss of support from the north side of the west wall. C. cladosporioides and Bacillus cereus were retrieved from opaque stains found in the center and south side of the west wall and Sphingomonas paucimobillis was isolated from the west side of the south wall from an area with discoloration. In regard to the ceiling, C. cladosporioides, Staphylococcus warnerii and Aspergillus section Fumigati were retrieved from the northwest side of the painting and P. citrinum and Aspergillus section Fumigati from the southeast side. They were retrieved from cracks and dark stains. The isolation of microbial agents shows a direct colonization of the surfaces that contributes significantly to the airborne concentration of spores, since the positive sampling areas correspond with the highest aerial concentration of microorganisms. This colonization has also been found in other paintings of the NTCR like Carlo Ferrario’s Musas I and II where Penicillium, Cladosporium and Bacillus were the main agents of biodeterioration identified22.Cladosporium spp. (the most frequently isolated fungi within the NTCR) is also the main biological agent described in biodeterioration processes in wall paintings27. This agent was found in several sampling sites in the MO and in the passive and active aerial studies. The deterioration mechanism described by Savkovic28 and collaborators indicates that the fungus can cause surface deterioration, causing brown discoloration stains, or even deep penetrating the artwork, surpassing the layer of paint and reaching the support. This is achieved through mechanical activities, such as the penetration of hyphae that increases the internal pressure of the painting leading to the formation of cracks. In addition, it causes damage through the chemical activity of extracellular enzymes secreted by the fungus when trying to use paint components as a source of nutrients. A study conducted in Brazil found that spores of Cladosporium cladosporioides and C. spinulosum are also capable of secreting enzymes for cellulose metabolism, which is a finding of special importance for museums with artworks made of wood29.Fungi of the genus Penicillium sp. have also been described in the literature as fungal agents of biodeterioration. It has been shown that Penicillium spores are capable of surviving in indoor environments for long periods of time, in addition to being dry-walled spores, which makes them light and easily dissociable from their reproductive structures30. These characteristics make the spores of this microorganism easily airborne and ideal for colonization of internal spaces such as the NTCR MO. Regarding relevant enzymes in the process of wear and tear of artistic artworks, different enzymes with proteolytic and cellulolytic activity, such as caseases and cellulases, have been found in vitro studies28. These enzymes can degrade numerous common substrates used in the production of artistic artworks, such as silk, wool, adhesives of layers of paint, paper, among others. Savkovic and collaborators also found that several species of Penicillium can excrete exopigments of different colors depending on the environmental conditions in which the fungus is found, which also contributes to the aesthetic degradation of artworks. One of the conditions that can favor the formation of these pigments is the availability of carbon, which could be found in high concentrations in this NTCR enclosure due to the external contamination to which it is exposed that was mentioned above.As for the bacteria, the highest number of isolates obtained from both the walls and the ceiling, were of the genus Staphylococcus. The members of the genus Staphylococcus are Gram-positive cocci that produce biofilms (polysaccharide matrixes) which allow them to adhere to many different surfaces31, in this case paintings. S. paucimobilis is a Gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium found in soil, aquatic and hospital environments. It produces a yellow pigment and is mobile through flagelli32. Finally, B. cereus is a Gram-positive rod also commonly found in soil and food. It is worth mentioning that it produces spores that are resistant to adverse environmental conditions, such as extreme temperatures, different pHs and low humidity33. This adaptation has allowed it to be a bacterium usually found colonizing the paintings of the NTCR22. Although the impairment implications of bacterial agents have not been studied as extensively as fungal agents, they have been found to possess similar enzymes such as proteases, esterases, and lipases34, plus the virulence factors previously described, which help these organisms degrade and discolor pigments frequently used in the elaboration of paintings and murals, such as black, red, and yellow ochre, among others.Atmospheric measurements in the MO at the NTCRMeasuring and monitoring temperature and relative humidity is necessary in historical and heritage buildings, along with other parameters like physical agents or light are highly recommended35,36. Natural ventilation from the windows of the MO is the mechanism mostly used in the NTCR, according to the information given by the personnel. From the observed data on wind velocity, temperature, and relative humidity at various points in the room, it was found that there were minimal variations when the windows were closed but slightly more when some of the windows were open. This is expected, as the airflow in the room was very low, as indicated by the air flow speed measurements. Nevertheless, when one of the windows or both windows were open, the values of wind speed, temperature and relative humidity changes as can be seen in Fig. 4A and Supplementary Figure S3. For the wind speed measurements, with the windows closed, the local wind velocity in the room averaged is about 0.06 m/s, with a standard deviation of 0.01 m/s. When the windows were opened, wind speeds increased to 0.35 m/s at the west window and 0.83 m/s at the south window. In the center of the room, the wind speed was 0.46 m/s. The standard deviation for these measurements ranged from 0.32 m/s to 0.49 m/s. This higher variation is expected due to the diverse airflow directions, which result in greater air movement and higher wind speed values (see Fig. 4A). For comparison, the study conducted at Matera Cathedral in southern Italy should be noted. The reported summer conditions included an average temperature ranging from \(15\,^{\circ }\)C to \(32\,^{\circ }\)C, an average relative humidity of around 80 %, and an average wind speed of 2.9 m/s37. This research also recommended a maximum temperature of \(25\,^{\circ }\)C and a relative humidity of 65 % for preserving mural paintings.Fig. 4Environmental conditions monitored in the Management Office of the National Theater of Costa Rica. The aim of characterizing these variables is that they correspond to the main factors that provide the greatest probability of playing a decisive role in the indoor hall that has been exposed during all the years since its exhibition and therefore, these indices serve as a guide and orientation for the observations reported below. The results of this study in the MO are consistent with a HMR index of medium to high and a PRD index which implies that people feel the chamber too hot38. However, these indices, therefore, need to be interpreted with caution39 since one should bear in mind that this historic heritage building is in the extreme climate and humidity of the tropics in Latin America.Air particle concentrations40 measurements were as follows: PM1 at 3.7 \({\upmu }\hbox {g/m}^3\), PM2.5 at 4.1 \({\upmu }\hbox {g/m}^3\), and PM10 at 4.8 \({\upmu }\hbox {g/m}^3\). However, opening a second window creates an entrance and an exit, promoting airflow and natural ventilation and, as a consequence, it can reduce the probability of particle sedimentation and reduces the relative humidity in the room as mentioned above9.Simulation of flow and accumulation’s probability of particlesUsing the Discrete Phase Model (DPM) in the ANSYS simulation, as a predictive tool, Fig. 4B illustrates how particles and airflow lines traverse the room when one of the windows is open. The particle and wind flow lines indicate turbulence on the north side of the room, where whirlwinds and backflows accumulate. Conversely, the flow on the other side of the room remains linear and orderly. Due to the rectangular shape of the room, the incoming and exiting air has more space to flow through the south window than the west window, as the west window has a closer wall constraining the airflow. As the velocity of the flow increases the turbulence also increases42, but according to natural ventilation, this turbulence may be desirable because it goes against buoyancy, and could help the movements of particles to not get deposited in the walls or ceiling of the MO43.The concentration of particles on the ceiling and the east wall was similar across the four studied scenarios: air entering through the south window or the west window, and at average and maximum wind velocities. This is because, as shown in the flow lines of the simulation, when the air flow incomes from the west window the flow bounces on the east wall and accumulates on the ceiling. This indicates that the flow could affect the paintings and increase the concentration of particles in this part of the paintings.In the simulations, when air enters through the south window, the flow has more space to move through the room, resulting in a more laminar pattern with fewer vortices and less impact on the ceiling paintings. In the scenario where the wind entrance is by the south window, the particles are still more concentrated on the north side of the painting according to the concentration map of the simulation.For the east wall with the mural, there is a space between the desk and a chair where the airflow creates whirlwinds. At the same time, it is consistent with the results obtained in the ANSYS simulation, which assumes that there is a greater deterioration due to the possibility of spore accumulation in those segments.Compelling the colour paletteTo identify the internal nature of the degradation observed in Serra’s artwork, we devised an exploratory minimally invasive sampling of the northern region of interest. From the experimental data in Fig. 5A and Table 6, it is quite revealing to assess the artist’s colour palette habituated during this period of time to fabricate the apparent green colour 45. Figure 6A exhibits one of the regions of interest chosen to collect millimetric samples (roughly 0.5 \(\hbox {mm}^{2}\)) with a scalpel from slightly damaged locations. As can also be seen from Fig. 6B46, we carried out an identification of the fluorescent pigment47 with madder lake from the Pigment Checker from Cultural Heritage Science Open Source (CHSOS)12. In order to observe the stratigraphies of individual samples using optical microscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and energy dispersive X ray spectroscopy (EDX), we embedded cross sections in epoxy resin which corroborate the following findings: (1) the structure corresponds to typically 2 to 4 layers, (2) based on crystals morphology and apparent colour, the elemental composition and historical knowledge, we inferred the associate pigment used by the artist, (3) the materials for the ground coincide with barium sulphate (\(\hbox {BaSO}_{4}\)) of natural origin i.e. barite, lead white (\(\hbox {Pb(OH)}_{2} \cdot\)2PbCO) and small traces of calcium carbonate (\(\hbox {CaCO}_{3}\)), (4) the secondary green colour was assembled using natural ultramarine (\(\hbox {Na}_{7}\hbox {Al}_{6}\hbox {Si}_{6}\hbox {O}_{24}\hbox {S}_{3}\)) and yellow ocher (\(\alpha\)-FeOOH) pigments. The elemental composition of the region of interest of the cross-section was identified by SEM-EDX48, see Fig. 6A.5, in order to determine the average size of each pigment and conduct the first ever study on Serra’s palette. Table 5 presents an overview of the particle size along with the complex morphology of each material used which allow us, based on evidence, to suggest that the ultramarine pigment and barite is from a natural origin. We hypothesize that the ground contains mainly barite, lead white pigment all mixed with traces of calcium carbonate. The last column includes the main elements for every type of pigment.Full size tableConclusionsThese research aimed to examine for the first time Serra’s paintings under non-controlled environmental conditions in a historic heritage building. It methodically assesses the deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration, along with the artist’s color palette. One of the most significant outcomes of this cutting-edge multidisciplinary research, assembled by our fluid simulation using solid particle dynamics in the environment chamber along with experimental data of wind speed, temperature, and particle size, among others, was the recognition of specific zones, at the artworks, which could be affected by their visual appearance over the time since the painting’s creation. The second major finding to emerge was that following the regions of interest previously obtained, we identified a considerable amount of deterioration patterns, biodeterioration microorganisms, and degradation of colour in the paintings. This finding has important suggestions for establishing affordable, compact, efficient, accessible, and novel non-destructive techniques, especially in the extreme climate and humidity of the tropics in Latin America in historic heritage buildings. The third significant finding of this investigation was that in an exploratory experiment we recognized the main artist’s colour palette, which includes: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine, and natural barite. There is abundant room for further progress in determining the stratigraphic’s internal nature of the degradation of colour discovered in the outer green layers of the painting.MethodsPiece of study and characteristicsThe artwork of the ceiling (Danthe and Raphael) in the MO of the NTCR is made with the marouflage technique, which consists of adhering manufactured artworks on a flexible support to a more rigid support. Due to its large dimensions, the support was made with tongue and groove joint wood. On the other hand, the mural was made on a brick support covered with stucco, the same material used in the construction of the NTCR building6,14.According to the information given by the administration of the NTCR and the observation, during approximately 1998 there was a restoration of the artworks in this room. Specifically for the murals they did a reintegration of the colour and improved the support of the mural. In the case of the ceiling, there is no documental, experienced, or physical evidence of a restoration. The administration has established some preventive conservation, which includes restricted public access inside the room and natural ventilation during some days of the week51.Multispectral imagingWe generated visible (VIS) and ultraviolet (UV) photographs based on the procedure described by our previous investigations12,13. Briefly, photographs were acquired using a Nikon D5300 camera with an AF-S DX Micro-NIKKOR 40mm f/2.8G lens, and was adjusted in order to obtain high resolution photos (24 megapixels). A white balance was carried out for all the photographs 52 and a pigment reference named Cultural Heritage Open Source Pigments Checker (CHSOS) pigment reference was used.Aerial fungal contamination of the NTCRThe fungal contamination of seven rooms of the NTCR was determined by measuring the concentration of aerial fungal spores via an active sampling. The former names of the sampled areas were Hall next to the Ladies’ Cafeteria, Men”s Canteen, Hall next to the Men’s Canteen, NTCR Management Office, Smoking Lounge for Ladies, Smoking Lounge for Men, and the Presidential Teather Box (see Supplementary Figure S1). These locations were selected because large format paintings are found there . A Burkard Personal Volumetric Air Sampler (Burkard Manufacturing Co. Ltd., United Kingdom) was used to collect the airborne spore particles53. The samples were collected on the last Friday of every month, for a year, starting in January 2022 (except in June and December because the NTCR was closed on said dates due to a hurricane and holidays, respectively). The instrument operates at a nominal air throughput of 10 liters per minute and deposits them onto a glass slide covered by a thin layer of Vaseline or petroleum gel. The spores obtained through the layer of Vaseline, were counted and identified using a light microscope Olympus CX31 (Olympus Life Science, Waltham, MA, USA) at 400 X. Identification of species and groups of interest was done using the atlas “Aeroallergen Identification” (American College of Allergy and Immunology, University of Michigan, November 10th, 1999). The significant differences between the spore concentration by month were determined using a one-way ANOVA test with a Post Hoc Tukey. Statistical significance was defined using a p value less than 0.05. The statistical analysis was made with the software SPSS version 20 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, Ill, USA).Aerial contamination of the MODue to the high fungal spore concentration found in the MO during the yearly survey, further studies were conducted: passive and active (volumetric) air samplings. For the passive samplings, three Petri dishes: blood agar (BA), standard agar (SA), and Sabouraud glucose agar (SGA) were left open for 15 minutes at each site and for the volumetric or active analysis, the Burkard Personal Volumetric Air Sampler from Burkard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. was used (see description in the Aerial fungal contamination of the NTCR). The Petri dishes from the passive air sampling were transported to the Medical Mycology Section laboratory at the School of Microbiology of the Universidad de Costa Rica, where they were incubated at \(37\,^{\circ }\)C (BA and SA) for 72 h and at \(25\,^{\circ }\)C (AGS) for three weeks. After incubation, the colonial morphotypes were analyzed and colony counts were performed. Seventeen sampling sites were selected for these experiments (Fig. 3B). The first nine were taken at the center of the room at three different elevation levels (ground level, 1.3 m and 2.6 m). These are the same locations described on Methods section Atmospheric measurements of the room. The other eight were taken at ground level, next to the positive sampling sites for fungal and bacterial isolation obtained from these surfaces (Supplementary Figure S2).Isolation of microorganisms from the murals and ceiling of the MOTwo sampling dates for isolation of microorganisms were conducted: June \(16^{th}\), 2023 (murals) and February \(9^{th}\), 2024 (ceiling). The samples were collected using dry sterile swabs that were rubbed over the sections of interest. Sampling sites were previously selected by an expert artist criterion: ten sampling sites from the murals and 24 from the ceiling painting. (Supplementary Figure S2). After the collection of samples, the swabs were immersed in 5 mL of 0.1 % Sterile Peptone Water and then transported at \(4\,^{\circ }\)C to the laboratory for further analysis. The swabs were used to inoculate BA, for bacterial isolation, and SGA with antibiotics (gentamicin and chloramphenicol) for fungi. The BA plates were incubated for 48 hours at \(35\,^{\circ }\)C. After incubation, bacterial colonies were microscopically analyzed with Gram staining, and later, they were identified using the \(\hbox {VITEK}^{\circledR }\) 2 System (bioMérieux, Marcy-L’Etoile, France). Each culture was deposited at a temperature of -80 ºC in a Brain Heart Infusion Broth supplemented with glycerol. On the other hand, at \(25\,^{\circ }\)C, the SGA plates were daily assessed for approximately three weeks. Subcultures of the different colonial morphotypes were performed on SGA and Potato Dextrose Agar. The purity and preliminary identification of the isolates were determined with lactophenol blue and clear lactophenol for hyaline and black fungi, respectively. Yeasts were identified using the \(\hbox {VITEK}^{\circledR }\) 2 System while filamentous fungi employing the \(\hbox {VITEK}^{\circledR }\)MS (bioMérieux, Marcy-L’Etoile, France).Atmospheric measurements of the roomAlso , due to our findings from the aerial fungal concentration data, we decided to measure the environmental properties of the room and outside, measuring: temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and concentration of particulate matter.Using an Arduino-based air sensor developed by the Climatic Systems Observation Laboratory (LOSiC) for applied meteorology of the Universidad de Costa Rica, measurements were taken of temperature, wind speed, relative humidity, and concentration of particles (PM 1, PM 2.5, and PM 10) every 5 s in a 5 to 15 minutes periods in the center of the room and by the windows. The room dimensions were taken by a Laser Distance Measure Bosch GLM 50-27 C.The first set of nine measurements points were made in the center of the room at three elevation levels (ground level, at 1.3 m and 2.6 m, following the same distribution as presented in Fig. 3D) and three columns going from north to south with all the windows closed. The second set of nine measurements were taken once in the center of the room, by the south window, and by the east window closest to the door (see Fig. 4A and Supplementary Figure S3) with three scenarios of one window open, both windows open and closed windows. Outside each window, measurements were also taken.Because the atmospheric station had three wind speed sensors arranged in a triangular configuration, the x-axis and y-axis wind speed measurements were calculated using the following equations:$$\begin{aligned} & V_{x} = V_{1}-\frac{(V_{2}+V_{3})}{2}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (1)
                $$\begin{aligned} & V_{y} = \frac{\sqrt{3}(V_{2}-V_{3})}{2}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (2)
                $$\begin{aligned} & V = \sqrt{V_{x}^{2}+V_{y}^{2}}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (3)
                where \(V_{1}\), \(V_{2}\), and \(V_{3}\) indicate the speed measured by the sensors [m/s]; \(V_{x}\), \(V_{y}\), V correspond to the wind speed in the x, y axis [m/s], and its magnitude, respectively.The analysis for the mass flow of the particles was made with a fixed box model, which is used for air pollution analysis in cities described by De Nevers41. These models establish a mass balance in the control volume of the air in the city to be zero (i.e. \(m_{entrance}-m_{exit}=0\)). In accordance, in this model, the entrance flow is the particle flow entering through the south (or west) windows and the particles created in the room, which are assumed to be zero. The exit flow consists of particles exiting through the opposite west (or south) windows and the particles accumulated on the paintings and the mural of the east wall.The mass flow, \(\dot{m}\), is therefore calculated using the wind speed magnitude (see Equation 3), concentration of particles in the air and the cross-sectional area of the window when they enter the room, following this relationship:$$\begin{aligned} \dot{m} = c\cdot V\cdot A_{t}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (4)
                here c denotes the air pollution concentration [\(\hbox {kg/m}^{3}\)] and \(A_{t}\) is related to the cross-sectional area of the entrance [\(\hbox {m}^{2}\)]. As a consequence, the entering particles can be considered suspended particles as the terminal sedimentation velocity is several orders of magnitude less than the local wind speed. The sedimentation terminal speed, \(V_{s}\), can be calculated with the Stokes law, as the particle’s size D are between 1 \({\upmu }\)m to 10 \({\upmu }\)m, given by:$$\begin{aligned} V_{s} = gD^{2}(\frac{\rho _{p}-\rho _{air}}{18\mu }), \end{aligned}$$
                    (5)
                where g corresponds to the gravity (9.81 \(\hbox {m/s}^{2}\)), \(\rho _{p}\) indicates the particle’s density = 2000 \(\hbox {kg/m}^{3}\), assuming that the air particles are similar in size to carbon, \(\rho _{air}\) is the air’s density = 1.2 \(\hbox {kg/m}^{3}\), and \(\mu\) correspond to the air’s dynamic viscosity = \(1.8x10^{-5}\) Pa\(\cdot\)s.Simulation of flow and accumulation’s probability of particlesUsing the measurements of the chamber, a 3D model was made in the platform for modelling Fusion \(360^{\circledR }\) for the control volume. This was imported to the software ANSYS 2023 R2 where an air flow simulation of the room was done. For the model, we considered a scenario where the south and west windows are open. According to the cleaning personnel, this is the most frequently used scenario. The mesh size is 0.1 m, using over 900 thousand elements, while there is a maximum of 1 million elements in this case. The east wall and the ceiling were considered as a particle trap to determine the number of particles trapped from the surrounding pollution.The model used for the analysis is a dense discrete particle model (DDPM) to incorporate the wind flow and the particle flow entering the room. The particles flow and the wind flow are inserted in the normal direction to the entrance of the windows at an average temperature of \(25\,^{\circ }\)C, a dispersion parameter of 4, a rosin-rammler distribution for the minimum diameter of 1 \(\mu\)m, an average diameter of 4.8 \(\mu\)m obtained from the room measurements and a maximum diameter of 10 \(\mu\)m. The mass flow is dependent on the velocity so for each case the mass flow is calculated keeping the cross-sectional area and the particle concentration constant. The simulation configuration will be with a stationary phase model, the standard K-\(\epsilon\) viscosity model, gravity, and the energy equation are included. The initialization will be with a hybrid model and the solution for 300 iterations.In the control volume, four scenarios will be simulated: the flow entrance is the south window, and when the flow entrance is the west window and for an average flow velocity and a maximum flow velocity.Selection of deteriorations: definition and characterizationThe definition and the characterization of the deteriorations found is presented in the Supplementary Table 2.Degradation of coluor analysisFor the study of the luminosity and spectral characteristics of the painting by Paolo Serra, the colorimeter with UCR plate 399759, brand KONICA MINOLTA and model CR20 was used. In this measuring instrument, colors are represented using coordinates in a uniform color space consisting of variable luminosity \(L^{*}\) and chromaticity indices \(a^{*}\) and \(b^{*}\). For this case, \(L^{*}\) indicates the scale from black to white, a negative value of \(a^{*}\) corresponds to color green, a positive value of \(a^{*}\) corresponds to color red, a negative value of the parameter \(b^{*}\) corresponds to blue and a positive value of \(b^{*}\) indicates closer to color yellow. The measurement of \(L^{*}\) (around 4-6 experimental points per zone) was carried out in all the regions previously established as areas of interest due to the high probability that particles would settle there, based on the simulation carried out with the ANSYS computer tool. As a consequence, it would be expected that, in the northern region of this painting, the variation of the \(L^{*}\) parameter would decrease since a lower value of \(L^{*}\) means a darker luminosity. Thus, \(L^{*}\) has been plotted as a function of the position on the grid of the painting (regions close to the frame), where the number 1 corresponds to the region closest to the windows, i.e. the western region of the NTCR, and 6 corresponds to the region closest to the west wall. The west and east walls have been divided into regions approximately similar in dimension to the north and south walls.Since color change can be a subjective variable54, and depends on the observer, data from colorimeter measurements were used to estimate possible color variations using the \(L^{*},a^{*},b^{*}\) diagram mentioned above. To do this, the difference in each of the coordinates \(L^{*}\), \(a^{*}\), and \(b^{*}\) is calculated, and the Euclidean difference between two measured points is calculated, as shown in Fig. 5A. The difference is estimated as follows:$$\begin{aligned} \Delta E=\sqrt{(\Delta L^{*})^{2}+(\Delta a^{*})^{2}+(\Delta b^{*})^{2}}, \end{aligned}$$
                    (6)
                here, \(\Delta L^{*}\) denotes the luminosity difference between the two extreme \(L^{*}\) cases (for example for the northern region, see Fig. 5A, grid 1 and grid 6); \(\Delta a^{*}\) denotes the chromaticity index difference between the two extreme \(a^{*}\) cases (for example for the northern region, see Fig. 5A, grid 1 and grid 6), and \(\Delta b^{*}\) denotes the chromaticity index difference between the two extreme \(b^{*}\) cases (for example for the northern region, see Fig. 5A, grid 1 and grid 6). Criteria 55,56 for establishing the colour difference between the six zones in the ceiling painting were carried out according to Table 6. The results obtained from the painting of \(\Delta E\) were represented as \(\Delta E_{exp}\) in order to compare it directly to standard reference values. To evaluate \(L^{*}\), \(a^{*}\), and \(b^{*}\), a global ANOVA F test was used for each variable. From the data, we obtained that the standard deviation for each case corresponds to 0.998, 0.562 and 0.935, respectively. Thus, a combined standard deviation for the whole group reveals a standard deviation of 0.638.Table 6 Optical assessment of the colour distances \(\Delta E\), see Equation 6, as Euclidean distances in the chromaticity diagram which corresponds to a sphere visualization of colour. “N”, “E”, “S”, and “W” corresponds to the northern, eastern, southern and western sides of the painting, respectively. The east and the west walls were divided into two regions.Full size tableOptical and UV microscopyWith the aim of studying the cross-section sample of Paolo Serra’s painting, the samples were collected under the supervision of the Manager of the NTCR Conservation Department, using a scalpel from damaged regions to minimize the risk of further damage. The samples were set up by embedding in epoxy resin (Fibrocentro®) and polishing them with water sanding sheets (3M®) of 9.2 \(\mu\)m, 6.5 \(\mu\)m, 3 \(\mu\)m and 1 \(\mu\)m grit sizes for approximately 3 min with each sheet, in descending order. For fine finishing, a EcoMet 30 Buehler®polisher was used, for two 15-min cycles with 15 \(\mu\)m and 3 \(\mu\)m alumina abrasive (Allied High-Tech Products®), under the following conditions: 150 rpm for stage and 150 rpm and 30 N force for the support arm, which rotated opposite to the stage. A DX.2053-PLPOLRi Delphi-X Observer microscope was used, as well as an equipped DC.18000-Pro Euromex digital camera along with a DT 1000 CE UV/VIS AIS light source was employed with a SR fiber type with a 600 \(\mu\)m core diameter (please see Fig. 6A). To obtain the complete view of the sample, a composition of 108 photos using Adobe Photoshop® was made, since the 20x magnitication allowed an aproppriate view of the sample but took small regions only; therefore, a composition of layers and a panorama had to be made (please see Fig. 6A.2). To avoid scale problems through this manipulation of the photos, the correct scale bar was included at the end, considering the longitude of the sample from two points and getting the reference from the SEM analysis, using the software ImageJ 1.54g. The latter to determine the pigment crystal distribution as shown in Table 5.Scanning electron microscope – energy dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (SEM–EDX)The samples were analyzed to determine their microstructure and elemental composition. Initially, they were examined using a stereoscope for macro photography. For microanalysis, each sample was mounted on a metal base and secured with double-sided carbon tape. Subsequently, the fragments were analyzed in a JEOL JSM-IT 500 scanning electron microscope under variable pressure, utilizing backscattered electron imaging to assess their structural characteristics. The SEM is equipped with a corresponding EDX detector, which facilitates elemental analysis of different areas of the sample, as well as specific crystals within cross sections.

              All data needed to evaluate the conclusions in the manuscript are present in the manuscript or the Supplementary Information and are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.
